senses.sense_definition: Of two objects, positioned at right angles or perpendicular to each other.

examples.text: The architect ensured that the walls were perfectly <w>orthogonal</w> to the floor.
In this coordinate system, the three axes are mutually <w>orthogonal</w>.

senses.sense_definition: Of two or more aspects of a problem or design, able to be treated separately because changes in one do not affect the others.

examples.text: Good software architecture keeps the user interface <w>orthogonal</w> to the database logic.
An <w>orthogonal</w> instruction set allows programmers to combine commands freely without unexpected side effects.

senses.sense_definition: Of two or more subjects, independent of or irrelevant to each other.

examples.text: His personal political views are <w>orthogonal</w> to his ability to perform the job professionally.
That argument is interesting, but it is <w>orthogonal</w> to the main point of our discussion.

senses.sense_definition: Statistically independent, with reference to variates.

examples.text: The researchers ensured that the variables in the experiment were <w>orthogonal</w> to avoid confounding results.
In this model, the error terms are assumed to be <w>orthogonal</w> to the predictors.

senses.sense_definition: Of a square matrix: such that its transpose is equal to its inverse.

examples.text: An <w>orthogonal</w> matrix preserves the dot product of vectors.
Calculations are often simplified when the transformation matrix is <w>orthogonal</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A line that appears to recede toward a vanishing point in a perspective drawing.

examples.text: The artist used <w>orthogonals</w> to create a convincing sense of depth in the painting.
You can find the vanishing point by tracing the <w>orthogonals</w> back to where they intersect.
